Jim & all,

I see, perhaps it was just a common technique use on different =
items.  Swords, Nagamaki, boken and shinai.

Moses
  ----- Original Message=
 ----- 
  From: Jim Gilbert 
  To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com 
  Sent: Tu=
esday, June 03, 2003 1:56 PM
  Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Nerikawa Nagamak=
i Tsuba FYI


  Tom & all,
  I haven't seen the koshirae for years, but bas=
ed on Keith's description and what I remember, this guard is mounted on the=
 pole (not the nakago) and would have served as a hand stop rather than a b=
lade stop.  The iron parrying bars would have taken care of other blades.  =
I don't recall anything about the leather plate that would suggest that it =
wasn't contemporary with the rest of the mounting, but my memory of it isn'=
t good enough to base an argument on.  There is a somewhat similar koshirae=
 at the bottom of page 82 of Bottomley and Hopson's "Arms and Armor of the =
Samurai."  Scanned here for your convenience:
  http://tinyurl.com/dd82

  =
I suppose it's possible that someone transplanted a shinai tsuba onto the n=
agamaki koshirae.  But on the other hand if you set out to make a round lea=
ther guard to go on a round wooden stick, I'm not sure how one for a nagama=
ki pole would or should look different from one for a shinai.  Any ideas?

=
  If we were talking about a loose guard not associated with a koshirae, I'=
d agree with Mo that it's much more likely to have been from a shinai or bo=
kken than a nagamaki.  But this one did come on a nagamaki and we have othe=
r examples of pole arms mounted like this with a hand guard on the pole and=
 parrying bars either mounted on the nakago or on the pole.  Am I missing s=
omething?
  Jim 

  --


    <http://tinyurl.com/d2ee>http://tinyurl.com/d2=
ee

    Jim-
          I just got around to looking at this. Check the size=
 of that 
    hole dude!=DD Are you sure this is original to the pole? This=
 looks 
    like a kendo shinai tsuba, a very old one but I would bet it is=
 for a 
    shinai none the less.
    Tom
